definitions.definition: a wooden or metal bar placed around something as a barrier or to provide support

examples.text: She leaned on the ship's rail and gazed out to sea.
He climbed onto the top fence rail.
She held tightly on to the rail.
After the accident a guard rail was placed all the way along the cliff path.
He came slowly down the stairs, holding the banister rail.

definitions.definition: a bar fixed to the wall for hanging things on

examples.text: a curtain rail
A black dress was hanging on the rail.
Lace curtains hung from the brass rails over the bed.
He put the towel back on the rail.

definitions.definition: each of the two metal bars that form the track that trains run on

examples.text: The train thundered along the rails.
The train came off the rails.
Trams run along rails.
Weeds grew between the rails.
A child was seen crossing the rails.
The gun is mounted on rails.

definitions.definition: railways as a means of transport

examples.text: to travel by rail
rail travel/services/fares
a rail link/network
He uses a combination of commuter rail and underground to get to work.
Many business people now opt for high-speed rail rather than flying.
We went from London to Budapest by rail.
the Channel Tunnel rail link
efforts to modernize the rail network

definitions.definition: to become successful again after a period of failure, or to begin functioning normally again

examples.text: He has helped get the company back on the rails again.

definitions.definition: to start behaving in a way that is strange or unacceptable, for example drinking a lot or taking drugs

examples.text: She went completely off the rails after her sister died.
He was worried his son was going to go completely off the rails.

definitions.definition: to lose control and stop functioning correctly

examples.text: The company has gone badly off the rails in recent years.

wordOrigin: noun Middle English: from Old French reille ‘iron rod’, from Latin regula ‘straight stick, rule’.
